metadata.synopsis: The Player manages to see the hidden text about Prince orpheus behind it. After the dialog, the book is updated with the true text and becomes a normal book.If players have obtained Chapter 2 from the boy, they unlock the book automatically.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Avatar or Orphaned Companion Laezel reads the orpheus chapters 1 and 3. Only happens when interacting with a chapter that is not yet properly Read.

8.speaker: Lae'zel
8.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Companion Laezel holds out the disk and examines it.

|Reuse from PLA_GithChokepoint_ReadingMap|

73.speaker: Lae'zel
73.text: It resembles the slate from Crèche Y'llek. I see similar patterns among the glyphs.

114.speaker: Lae'zel
114.text: Ah - another chapter of the Orpheus tale.

18.speaker: Lae'zel
18.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Part One.'
18.context: NodeContext: ghaik = gayk. Reading a story.

111.speaker: Lae'zel
111.text: 'So it was that we were free from ghaik shackles and turned our blades on each other. The heavens were shattered, and one great empire was divided in two.'
111.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

49.speaker: Lae'zel
49.text: 'Gith travelled to the Hells to broker help for her people, her cause. Vlaakith would have you believe Mother Gith proclaimed her our queen.'
49.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

65.speaker: Lae'zel
65.text: 'Lies! Gith made no such proclamation. Vlaakith seized the empire against the Mother's wishes.'
65.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

4.speaker: Lae'zel
4.text: 'But Gith had nurtured a son. Orpheus, Prince of the Comet, the True Heir! He knew Vlaakith's treachery.'
4.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

7.speaker: Lae'zel
7.text: 'Orpheus rallied Gith's honour guard and declared the throne for himself. The War of the Comet had begun.'
7.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

30.speaker: Lae'zel
30.text: The slate holds the truth. The prince still comes for his throne.

103.speaker: Lae'zel
103.text: Truth or not, it matters no longer. Orpheus is fallen. Vlaakith reigns supreme.
103.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

108.speaker: Lae'zel
108.text: Incredible tale. I wouldn't have believed it, if we hadn't seen the prince for ourselves.

100.speaker: Lae'zel
100.text: A profane tale. These lies must perish with the prince who told them.

13.speaker: Lae'zel
13.text: This - this is drivel, surely. Gith declared Vlaakith queen of the empire, and her own son defied her. Orpheus would have ceded control to the ghaik.

104.speaker: Lae'zel
104.text: And yet - what if it's true? Could the City of Death have risen from a single Great Lie?

27.speaker: Lae'zel
27.text: Tsk'va. Mother Gith, I implore you - show us truth.

89.speaker: Lae'zel
89.text: All of it, drivel. Gith declared Vlaakith queen of the empire, and her own son defied her. Orpheus would have ceded control to the ghaik.
89.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

87.speaker: Lae'zel
87.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Part Three.'
87.context: NodeContext: Reading a story. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

61.speaker: Lae'zel
61.text: 'The histories tell us that Commander Voss, Jhe'stil Kith'rak, pierced Prince Orpheus clean through with his sword of silver. That his flesh was torn and fed to the great red dragon Ephelomon.'
61.context: NodeContext: Reading a story, matter of factly. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

46.speaker: Lae'zel
46.text: 'Vlaakith's faithful roar out this tale. But beneath the roars, we hear whispers carrying truth and prophecy.'

58.speaker: Lae'zel
58.text:
'The Prince of the Comet is not dead.
The Prince of the Comet will come again.
The Prince of the Comet will liberate us from Vlaakith's tyranny.'

37.speaker: Lae'zel
37.text: 'Praise be to Mother Gith, Queen of the One Sky! Praise be to your son Orpheus, the True Heir, Prince of the Comet!'

79.speaker: Lae'zel
79.text: The story is true - Orpheus is free. And right here, right now, we are writing its next chapter.

83.speaker: Lae'zel
83.text: We know how this story truly ends. With the death of the prince, and a throne left unchallenged.
83.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

63.speaker: Lae'zel
63.text: Vlaakith has reigned unchallenged for millennia. Freeing Orpheus could be the first strike in a new war - as well as its last.

77.speaker: Lae'zel
77.text: Tsk'va. A failed prophecy. The Prince of the Comet will not live long enough to seize Vlaakith's throne.

91.speaker: Lae'zel
91.text: No, no. Gith's son died to Voss' blade. Orpheus is no more.

0.speaker: Lae'zel
0.text: This is more than a fable - it's an affront to the Undying Queen Vlaakith. Gith's son died to Voss' blade. Orpheus is no more.

94.speaker: Lae'zel
94.text: But every glyph is bent or mirrored, every symbol disordered. I can make no sense of it -

17.speaker: Lae'zel
17.text: Ah, the cipher. I can use it to bring un-muddle this mess. Yes, I see shape, I see structure. I see - a story.

55.speaker: Lae'zel
55.text: Wait. The ga'varsh taught us how to decipher the ancient texts. Let me think.

64.speaker: Lae'zel
64.text: Ah, I see the pattern. The writings are - fables. No, beyond fables. Heresies.

29.speaker: Lae'zel
29.text: It shouldn't take much effort to decipher it. And... there. From madness rises meaning.

10.speaker: Narrator
10.text: *The tir'su engraved on the disc are ancient, but you recognise most of the symbols thanks to your rigorous studies on Crèche K'liir.*
10.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Avatar Laezel holds out the disk and examines it.

|Reuse from PLA_GithChokepoint_ReadingMap|NodeContext: Cresh keh-LEAR. TEAR-soo.

36.speaker: Narrator
36.text: *As with the boy's slate in the mountain crèche, there are hidden writings among the glyphs.*

92.speaker: Narrator
92.text: *Your mind reassembles the symbols and a story takes shape.*

99.speaker: Narrator
99.text: *'So it was that we were free from ghaik shackles and turned our blades on each other. The heavens were shattered, and one great empire was divided in two.'*
99.context: NodeContext: ghaik = gayk. Reading a story.

22.speaker: Narrator
22.text: *'Gith travelled to the Hells to broker help for her people, her cause. Vlaakith would have you believe Mother Gith proclaimed her our queen.'*

14.speaker: Narrator
14.text: *'Lies! Gith made no such proclamation. Vlaakith seized the empire against the Mother's wishes.'*
14.context: NodeContext: kith'raki = kith-RACK-ee. Reading a story.

20.speaker: Narrator
20.text: *'But Gith had nurtured a son. Orpheus, Prince of the Comet, the True Heir! He knew Vlaakith's treachery.'*

3.speaker: Narrator
3.text: *'Orpheus rallied Gith's honour guard and declared the throne for himself. The War of the Comet had begun.'*

72.speaker: Narrator
72.text: *Once, you might not have believed such a tale. But a new war is coming - and Orpheus will battle once more for the throne that belonged to his mother.*

45.context: CinematicNodeContext: |Avatar Laezel puts the disk away.|

78.speaker: Narrator
78.text: *Whether the stories were true or fabrications, it matters no longer. Orpheus is fallen.*

98.speaker: Narrator
98.text: *Orpheus - no longer just a story, but a reality. Gith's son lives.*

70.speaker: Narrator
70.text: *It's a heretical tale. Your varsh taught that Orpheus defied the will of his mother Gith. He would have usurped the throne and weakened the empire.*

40.speaker: Lae'zel
40.text: But maybe the teachings weren't real. Maybe Vlaakith betrayed Gith and seized control.

5.speaker: Narrator
5.text: *Your thoughts don't sit well with you. Could Vlaakith really have sacrificed Gith in exchange for the dragon alliance - and control of the empire?*

67.speaker: Narrator
67.text: *And if so, what else has Vlaakith lied to her people about?*

51.speaker: Lae'zel
51.text: These writings are pure propaganda, the work of an insidious apostate.

50.speaker: Narrator
50.text: *You've dedicated your life to your queen. Through her, your mind is silver, and your body steel.*

88.speaker: Narrator
88.text: *Whoever speaks lies against Vlaakith must be decapitated and bisected, and their head brought to her court.*

31.speaker: Narrator
31.text: *This is the way. This is your queen's command.*

44.speaker: Lae'zel
44.text: It's just a story, as harmless as it is far-fetched.

16.speaker: Narrator
16.text: *Vlaakith gifted Gith to Tiamat in exchange for the red dragons? A ludicrous claim.*

80.speaker: Narrator
80.text: *Vlaakith's rein is too secure to be shaken by old legends. Orpheus is long dead, and the queen is unfaltering.*

90.speaker: Narrator
90.text: *You consider the tale. Vlaakith would call it profane. Only a heretic would think otherwise.*

35.speaker: Narrator
35.text: *'The histories tell us that Commander Voss, Jhe'stil Kith'rak, pierced Prince Orpheus clean through with his sword of silver. That his flesh was torn and fed to the great red dragon Ephelomon.*'
35.context: NodeContext: Reading a story. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

48.speaker: Narrator
48.text: *'Vlaakith's faithful roar out this tale. But beneath the roars, we hear whispers carrying truth and prophecy.'*

19.speaker: Narrator
19.text:
*'The Prince of the Comet is not dead.
The Prince of the Comet will come again.
The Prince of the Comet will liberate us from Vlaakith's tyranny.'*

62.speaker: Narrator
62.text: *'Praise be to Mother Gith, Queen of the One Sky! Praise be to your son Orpheus, the True Heir, Prince of the Comet!'*

21.speaker: Narrator
21.text: *This is no mere story. You have seen the truth unfold before your eyes. Orpheus will rise and guide the githyanki to freedom.*

2.speaker: Narrator
2.text: *The story was mere wishful thinking, of course. Orpheus is defeated, and the prophecy's failed. The lich queen reins eternal.*

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *A fantastical story. You would never have believed Orpheus lived, had you not seen him with your own eyes.*

43.speaker: Narrator
43.text: *It's a heretical tale. Your varsh taught that Orpheus died at Voss' hands, and for good reason. He would have usurped the throne and weakened the empire.*

107.speaker: Lae'zel
107.text: But maybe the teachings weren't real. Maybe Orpheus lives to this day.

112.speaker: Narrator
112.text: *Your thoughts don't sit well with you. Could Vlaakith really have lied about the death of Orpheus, Gith's only son?*

75.speaker: Lae'zel
75.text: These writings are pure propaganda, the work of an insidious apostate.

86.speaker: Lae'zel
86.text: It's just a story, as harmless as it is far-fetched.

110.speaker: Narrator
110.text: *Gith's son Orpheus still lives, and plans to depose Vlaakith? A ludicrous claim.*

97.speaker: Narrator
97.text: *Their meaning, however, is garbled, as if they are codes needing to be deciphered.*

69.speaker: Lae'zel
69.text: Use the cipher you found to reveal the true meaning.

9.speaker: Lae'zel
9.text: Think back on your lessons. Maybe you've learned how to unravel the cipher.

41.speaker: Narrator
41.text: *You remember a method of decoding cryptic tir'su. it appears to work even on these ancient texts.*

6.speaker: Lae'zel
6.text: Examine the tir'su closely, seeking greater understanding.

93.speaker: Narrator
93.text: *A pattern emerges. You've cracked the code.*

82.speaker: Narrator
82.text: *You can't make sense of the symbols, no matter how hard you try.*

52.speaker: Narrator
52.text: *Like before, the glyphs require some effort to translate.*

85.speaker: Lae'zel
85.text: This disc is embellished with tir'su script.
85.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Companion Laezel holds out the disk and examines it.

|Reuse from PLA_GithChokepoint_ReadingMap|

109.speaker: Narrator
109.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Avatar Laezel holds out the disk and examines it.

|Reuse from PLA_GithChokepoint_ReadingMap|NodeContext: TEAR-soo
